content.text: PHP Include Files
The include (or require ) statement takes all the text/code/markup that exists in the specified file and copies it into the file that uses the include statement.
content.html: The include (or require) statement takes all the text/code/markup that exists in the specified file and copies it into the file that uses the include statement.

content.text: Including files is very useful when you want to include the same PHP, HTML, or text on multiple pages of a website.
content.html: Including files is very useful when you want to include the same PHP, HTML, or text on multiple pages of a website.

content.text: PHP include and require Statements
It is possible to insert the content of one PHP file into another PHP file (before the server executes it), with the include or require statement.
content.html: It is possible to insert the content of one PHP file into another PHP file (before the server executes it), with the include or require statement.

content.text: The include and require statements are identical, except upon failure:
content.html: The include and require statements are identical, except upon failure:

content.text: So, if you want the execution to go on and show users the output, even if the include file is missing, use the include statement. Otherwise, in case of FrameWork, CMS, or a complex PHP application coding, always use the require statement to include a key file to the flow of execution. This will help avoid compromising your application's security and integrity, just in-case one key file is accidentally missing.
content.html: So, if you want the execution to go on and show users the output, even if the include file is missing, use the include statement. Otherwise, in case of FrameWork, CMS, or a complex PHP application coding, always use the require statement to include a key file to the flow of execution. This will help avoid compromising your application's security and integrity, just in-case one key file is accidentally missing.

content.text: Including files saves a lot of work. This means that you can create a standard header, footer, or menu file for all your web pages. Then, when the header needs to be updated, you can only update the header include file.
content.html: Including files saves a lot of work. This means that you can create a standard header, footer, or menu file for all your web pages. Then, when the header needs to be updated, you can only update the header include file.

content.text: Syntax

content.code_html:
include 'filename';

or

require 'filename';

content.text: PHP include Examples
Example 1
Assume we have a standard footer file called "footer.php", that looks like this:
content.html: Assume we have a standard footer file called "footer.php", that looks like this:

content.text: To include the footer file in a page, use the include statement:
content.html: To include the footer file in a page, use the include statement:

content.code:
Welcome to my home page!

Some text.

Some more text.
content.code_html:
<html>
<body>

<h1>Welcome to my home page!</h1>
<p>Some text.</p>
<p>Some more text.</p>
<?php include 'footer.php';?>

</body>
</html>

content.text: Example 2
Assume we have a standard menu file called "menu.php":
content.html: Assume we have a standard menu file called "menu.php":

content.code_html:
<?php
echo '<a href="/default.asp">Home</a> -
<a href="/html/default.asp">HTML Tutorial</a> -
<a href="/css/default.asp">CSS Tutorial</a> -
<a href="/js/default.asp">JavaScript Tutorial</a> -
<a href="default.asp">PHP Tutorial</a>';
?>

content.text: All pages in the Web site should use this menu file. Here is how it can be done (we are using a <div> element so that the menu easily can be styled with CSS later):
content.html: All pages in the Web site should use this menu file. Here is how it can be done (we are using a <div> element so that the menu easily can be styled with CSS later):

content.code:
Welcome to my home page!

Some text.

Some more text.
content.code_html:
<html>
<body>

<div class="menu">
<?php include 'menu.php';?>
</div>

<h1>Welcome to my home page!</h1>
<p>Some text.</p>
<p>Some more text.</p>

</body>
</html>

content.text: Example 3
Assume we have a file called "vars.php", with some variables defined:
content.html: Assume we have a file called "vars.php", with some variables defined:

content.text: Then, if we include the "vars.php" file, the variables can be used in the calling file:
content.html: Then, if we include the "vars.php" file, the variables can be used in the calling file:

content.code: Welcome to my home page!
content.code_html:
<html>
<body>

<h1>Welcome to my home page!</h1>
<?php include 'vars.php';
echo "I have a $color $car.";
?>

</body>
</html>

content.text: PHP include vs. require
The require statement is also used to include a file into the PHP code.
content.html: The require statement is also used to include a file into the PHP code.

content.text: However, there is one big difference between include and require; when a file is included with the include statement and PHP cannot find it, the script will continue to execute:
content.html: However, there is one big difference between include and require; when a file is included with the include statement and PHP cannot find it, the script will continue to execute:

content.code: Welcome to my home page!
content.code_html:
<html>
<body>

<h1>Welcome to my home page!</h1>
<?php include 'noFileExists.php';
echo "I have a $color $car.";
?>

</body>
</html>

content.text: If we do the same example using the require statement, the echo statement will not be executed because the script execution dies after the require statement returned a fatal error:
content.html: If we do the same example using the require statement, the echo statement will not be executed because the script execution dies after the require statement returned a fatal error:

content.code: Welcome to my home page!
content.code_html:
<html>
<body>

<h1>Welcome to my home page!</h1>
<?php require 'noFileExists.php';
echo "I have a $color $car.";
?>

</body>
</html>

content.text: Use require when the file is required by the application.
content.html: Use require when the file is required by the application.

content.text: Use include when the file is not required and application should continue when file is not found.
content.html: Use include when the file is not required and application should continue when file is not found.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
Which PHP syntax can NOT be used to include a file?
content.html: Which PHP syntax can NOT be used to include a file?
